title: German submarine U-131 (1941)
text:
German submarine "U-131" was a <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC">Type IXC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Built at the <a href="DeSchiMAG">DeSchiMAG</a> <a href="AG%20Weser">AG Weser</a> shipyard in <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a>, she was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 1 September 1940, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 1 April 1941, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 1 July 1941, with "<a href="Korvettenkapit%C3%A4n">Korvettenkapitän</a>" Arend Baumann in command.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC">German Type IXC submarines</a> were slightly larger than the original <a href="German%20Type%20IXB%20submarine">Type IXB</a>s. "U-131" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. The U-boat had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN</a> M 9 V 40/46 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> four-stroke, nine-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> 2 GU 345/34 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-131" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and two at the stern), 22 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="10.5%20cm%20SK%20C/32%20naval%20gun">SK C/32 naval gun</a>, 180 rounds, and a <a href="3.7%20cm%20SK%20C/30">SK C/30</a> as well as a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of forty-eight.
Service history.
"U-131" sailed from <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> on her first and only patrol on 27 November 1941.
On 6 December she torpedoed and sank the 4,016 ton British cargo ship "Scottish Trader", a straggler from convoy SC 56, en route from <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> to <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, south of <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>. All 43 of the crew perished.
On 17 December "U-131" was spotted by a <a href="Grumman%20Martlet">Grumman Martlet</a> aircraft from the <a href="escort%20carrier">escort carrier</a> while shadowing <a href="Convoy%20HG%2076">Convoy HG 76</a> as part of the "Seeräuber" (English: "Pirate", lit. "Sea Robber") <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>.
"U-131" was forced to dive, while ships of the <a href="36th%20Escort%20Group%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">36th Escort Group</a>, commanded by <a href="Frederic%20John%20Walker">Frederic John Walker</a> in , with four other escorts, including the destroyers , and and the corvette , approached to continue the attack. Detected by "Stanley"s <a href="ASDIC">ASDIC</a> (sonar), she was <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>d by "Pentstemon", and forced to surface, due to <a href="chlorine%20gas">chlorine gas</a> coming from the batteries. Unable to dive, she attempted to escape by running at full speed on the surface. While under pursuit "U-131" shot down an attacking Martlet aircraft, killing the pilot, but was then shelled by the escort group, which scored several hits. Realizing that the situation was hopeless, the crew abandoned the U-boat and scuttled her. All 47 of the crew survived and were taken prisoner.
